June 14, 1935
Dr, B. B. Brackett
Radio Station KUSD
University of South Dakota
Vermillion, S. D,
Dear Dr, Brackett:
As the representative of the National Association of Educational Broadcasters,
it has been my privilege and pleasure to attend meetings of the National Com¬
mittee on Education by Radio in Washington, D. C,, September 24, January 21,
and March 25.
As a result of serious consideration given to radio problems during the past
four hearings the NCER at its meeting on March 25, 1935, adopted a report of
a subcommittee on the proposal for a national supplemental public broadcasting
system. The report was presented before the joint meeting of the Sixth Annual
Institute for Education by Radio and the Fifth Annual Assembly of the National
Advisory Council on Radio in Education on May 7, at Columbus, Ohio, by Dr. A,
G-, Crane, president of the University of Wyoming,
Dr. Crane is chairman of the radio committee of the National Association of
State Universities and vicechairman of the National Committee on Education by
Radio. The proposal as presented by Dr, Crane was well received by the joint
assembly and,in the discussion that followed,much was found to commend the
plan and little criticism was offered. This proposal for a national supple¬
mental public broadcasting system was again effectively presented by Dr. Crane
at the hearing before the Federal Communications Commission in Washington, May
16. At the conclusion of the hearing, Chairman Sykes announced that further
study of the plans proposed for improving educational broadcasting would be
made by a committee to be appointed by the Federal Communications Commission
and headed by the United States Commissioner of Education, Dr. J. W. Studebaker.
The other members of the committee will be announced later.
